title: Who will win the 2020 South Carolina Democratic primary?
preds: Calling it a toss up given new surge of Biden in polls.  I suspect sanders is undervalued still. His supporters are more passionate. His under thirty supporters have gotten an extra cohort and should be energized enough to rock up to vote Biden doesn’t command as passionate support but is well like able enough in the black community to get the social approval. Given primary and not caucus there may still be a difference between public and private support
Updating based on 538's most recent analysis indicating a 95% chance that Biden wins most delegates

The latest polls show a resurgence in Biden's support. As predicated, his campaign team is working overtime to make sure he wins South Carolina, while Bernie by contrast has already moved on to the Super Tuesday states. This is also evidence that his second place finish in Nevada, especially over Buttigieg was enough to revitalize his campaign and support in South Carolina, that paired with decent debate performances is enough to keep him going and to secure a win in the South.

Since the new polls show Biden consistently in the lead, it's fairly safe to think that he is in the lead. However, his lead has materialized rather quickly, and may fade just as quickly. Nevertheless, the lead is there, so while Biden may not win by a large margin, he'll probably win. But the twenty-point-lead poll is literally fantastic - that is, it's a fantasy.
Updating to reflect favorable polling data for Biden.
With a recent important endorsement Biden will almost certainly win.
All signs/polls pointing to slow Joe. Why?!

Updating estimates based on recent polls, including those post-Nevada. According to 538 Biden has a 10ppt lead over Sanders in their polling average. Biden's polling has improved markedly in the past week.
Polling is heavily in favor of Biden.

Another 20 point poll lead today for Biden (Monmouth). This pushes my prediction up to 86%. Model - 86%
FiveThirtyEight - 80%
Exchange - 90%
Increasing by 1% based on slight increases for Biden in poll updates.

(1) Consistent lead in the polls, with the most recent polls showing a little bit of a break towards Biden.
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/sc/south_carolina_democratic_presidential_primary-6824.html
(2) Endorsement today by Rep. James Clyburn.
updating on more SC polls. Plus Biden apparently had a pretty good debate with all the fire going towards Bloomberg + Sanders

There is significant changes in the numbers after the debate.
For this forecast, I used the updated crowd forecast, the prediction market [1] and the latest state poll reported in RealClear Politics [2]. I scaled the forecast to the top 3 (corrected from the last forecast because I missed Steyer who has 20% in the latest poll) candidates only.  [1] https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5409
[2] https://www.realclearpolitics.com/

Biden has pulled away over the last week and he now has an average lead of 8.5 points. My model suggests he has an 80% chance of victory. The exchange and FiveThirtyEight are not quite as confident at 78% and 73% but this will probably change in the coming days.

There is significant changes in the numbers after the debate.
For this forecast, I used the updated crowd forecast, the prediction market [1] and the latest state poll reported in RealClear Politics [2].  I scaled the forecast to the top 2 candidates only. [1] https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5409
[2] https://www.realclearpolitics.com/
I'm following fivethirtyeight.com, which currently has Biden at 73% and Sanders at 23%.
Updated after watching debate and seeing post-debate polls.
Taking recent polls into consideration after the SC debate.
Updated to reflect several good polls for Biden.

It does seem like Biden was able to consolidate is support in South Carolina, while Steyer's popularity is faltering. Biden's support does seem to be over the critical 25% with Bernie just below. That said Biden polling data is known to be an overestimation of his actual support on election day, but it does seem like he'll be able to hang onto his traditional lead despite his failings.

Making it even up, given that all recent polls put Biden in the lead. We'll see if Republican hijinks in the Democratic primary make a difference. It looks like Steyer is not really a factor, despite his spending a pile of money on ads and his pandering with reparations.

Five-Thirty-Eight polls continue to consistently rate Biden ahead of Bernie.
Despite what I think - I have to go with the polls this late in the game.
It's Biden's state to lose, but the Bernie movement is strong.

Tom Steyers is the spoiler here taking 19% with his reparaitions discussion during the debate with crickets from other candidates. 65% of democrats are black. Joe just seems like an angry man which I am not sure appeals to black base. Maybe it does.

Biden has the Obama shine but Bernie on the rise as clear leader and treated as such. Gives him front runner creds  He is anti establishment. Meaning he has more passionate supporters, whereas moderates are Lukewarm to their candidates and will splinter the vote Have added few points more to Biden after debate
My forecast is based on current polls from FiveThirtyEight and forecast avg from PredictIt https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primary-forecast/south-carolina/

Feelin’ the Bern. Slow Joe woke up a bit but is yesterday’s man. Even South Carolina realizing that. Bernie has expanded his stretch to minorities. Slow Joe is showing his time has passed (should have been candidate 4 years ago).
Polls have been consistent and trending better for Biden in South Carolina.  The margin between Biden and Sanders is so wide, I feel comfortable going all-in for Biden.
Small update based upon recent events. Will better fine-tune my credence levels in 1-2 days.

Despite his poor performance in the first three primaries the chances of Biden winning here look promising. Although Sanders wins in NH and Nevada have boosted his polling Biden seems to have held on to a healthy poll lead (5% this week on average). My model suggests a lead such as this equates to 70% chance of victory. I'm going to downgrade this to 67% though as my model has been heavily influenced by the PPP poll (a Biden win by 15 points). I'm also thinking Sanders has a lot of momentum and his popularity could improve by Saturday. Model - 67%
FiveThirtyEight - 64%
Exchange - 59%
Weighted Ave. - 65%
Several polls from SC yesterday show biden in the lead.

Upping Biden's odds, but I still don't think he'll win. On the plus side for him; the latest poll has him clobbering Sanders. OK, maybe. Second, Clyburn's endorsement, which the press makes much of, and for all I know they should. But Biden has hundreds of endorsements from African-American office holders in South Carolina, so I doubt if one more, no matter how popular and esteemed the endorser is, will tip the balance decisively. On the debit side, Steyer is supposedly spending money hand over fist in South Carolina, and that may tell. Steyer, of course, won't win, but he doesn't have to to hurt Biden. He just has to bleed off enough support that Biden comes in second. We'll see if something like that happens.  But in my opinion the biggest story is Biden's effort to manage expectations going into South Carolina. There's this article from "The Hill:" https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/484372-biden-faces-do-or-die-primary-in-south-carolina Salient quote: "In an interview on "Face the Nation" on Sunday, Biden said he expects “to do well” in South Carolina.  But the former vice president pushed back on the notion that the state was his firewall.  “You said it’s my firewall, I’ve never said that,” he told host Margaret Brennan. “I’ve said I’m going to do well there.”  End quote. This is exactly the type of thing he said before he lost in Iowa and New Hampshire. In any case, it doesn't sound like a guy who's confident of winning.
PPP has a +15 Biden poll just out, with Steyer's support collapsed.
Biden latest polls gaining some momentum but Sanders also increasing. Very unlikely that anyone surges now.

tweaking slightly, knocking Warren down to zero (shown no appeal to ethnic minorities), upping Biden a bit (ahead in last poll but I still think Sanders is a reasonable favourite based on his momentum shown so far). Clyburn endorsement is another pro-Biden data point but honestly it's hard to evaluate if single endorsements matter much (am a bit skeptical).
Updating based off of Biden's rise in the polls and incoming Clyburn endorsement. Tomorrow's debate could easily change things.
Increased Bernies odds a bit. He is adding some stops in SC. Therefore his campaign thinks there is a chance he could win, or else they wouldn't waste time.

Bernie definitely has the momentum going into South Carolina, but Biden's base remains strong and his second place finish was exactly what his dying campaign needed to stay viable for South Carolina voters. Furthermore the latest poll out of South Carolina highlights that Biden's precipitous fall in the polls has either slowed or halted, putting him around the critical support level of the mid twenties, while Bernie remains in the low twenties. It is either of their game, but Biden has the upper hand on this one, the next few days are critical to watch to see if Biden can manage to hold on to his support.  While Steyer polls well, his actual support in Nevada was around half what polls predicted due the fact that he's not perceived as a viable candidate, i.e. hasn't received any delegates or much media attention or even done well. Therefore, a similar outcome should be expected in South Carolina where the polls for his support are in fact over inflated. Moreover, after an initial surge in support show in the polls, Steyer seems to have reached a threshold as he remains unable to poll above 20% sticking to around the mid to high teens for the past month, these aren't winning numbers and they shouldn't be expected to improve in the next week.  Nobody else polls remotely well enough to come out ahead of Biden or Bernie. Buttigieg should be watched, but it remain exceedingly unlikely for him to more than double his support in South Carolina, especially considering how he wasn't able to do it in Nevada in two weeks and has consistently lacked support of blacks and Latinos on election day. Moreover, after another 4th place finish in Nevada, even Warren's firey debate performance was not enough to resurrect her dying campaign.
Biden is confident but Sanders has momentum. Either Joe knows something we don't, or it is wishful thinking/flawed projections.
Sanders is polling strongly ini momentum as of current, but this is Biden country typically.
RCP poll and unpopularity of radicals in SE USA

Base rates from 538 of 46% v 40% for Bernie and Biden resp. Made changes to account for:
- Bernie clear front leader from Nevada
- Included Bernie's bad results from 2016 by keeping Biden's point in that ball parK +  Added points for someone. It wasn't his electorate, but besides Biden I don't see anybody who would get their vote otherwise  Also, Bernie's ideas feel less extreme now that we've heard them yelled for 4 years longer
Position changed due to Bernie leading in the prediction market.
Again, I think Biden will do his best in the Southern States. Sanders will give him a run for his money but Biden will take this primary which will give his campaign the fuel it needs to stay afloat.

The ground seems to be shifting out from under Biden. He still has got a good chance in South Carolina, but recent polls show him losing close to half the support he once enjoyed. With one of the latest putting him in a tie with Bernie. Biden's performance in Nevada will be a key indicator of whether he can hold onto South Carolina. If Biden is in the top three in Nevada, this will be good for his performance in Nevada, but if he's knocked off the podium, then he is likely going to lose his top place in South Carolina as well.
Polls say Biden and Sanders about tied.

Bernie's momentum out of Nevada probably makes him a slight favourite over Biden even though the state demographically isn't as good for him. I do struggle to believe that the 16% Steyer is currently polling will really hold up and if it doesn't I have no idea where that support will go, which is another complicating factor.

For what it's worth, an article from Politico: https://www.politico.com/news/2020/02/15/joe-biden-south-carolina-firewall-114862 The takeaway: some people say Biden's support among black voters in South Carolina is eroding. Some people say it isn't. We'll see how he does in Nevada, and if that affects his support in South Carolina and down the line. I expect it will.

Based on polling averages, Biden is considerably ahead. In 2016, despite fantastic performances in Iowa/ NH by Bernie he was summarily trounced in SC by Hillary. This state doesn't contain his core demographics. He will struggle to maintain momentum through SC.
Updating for recent polls. Biden has lost ground in this state but still remains in a commanding lead.

Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders poll best among black voters, a tranche that is extremely important in the SC Democratic primaries. Joe Biden's numbers have steeply dropped in recent weeks, hence why I no longer see him as the favorite. Elizabeth Warren I see with little to no chance of winning this primary. Tom Steyer, on the other-hand, has been pumping money into SC for months now. So I think Bernie is the likeliest to win. Biden is a second choice. Klobuchar could have a strong showing, Buttigieg could do well among younger black voters, but is polling terribly with older black voters.
Giving Biden 25%, based on polls. I still don't believe that he's that strong a candidate in South Carolina or anywhere else. But if he doesn't win South Carolina, he can forget it and go home.
The latest poll after NH shows Biden (28), Sanders (20), Steyer (14), Warren (7), Buttigieg (8), and Klobuchar (7), with 14% undecided.  I am going to amplify these numbers for the forecast.
This state is key to Biden’s survival. His support among older African-Americans is strong, but it has softened this past month with the VP’s stumbles and poor Iowa and New Hampshire performance.
Bernie is the likely winner because of his attraction to minority voters.  Biden generally has support in SC.  Buttigieg may surprise his competitors with a solid showing.

This should be Biden's place to shine, and to reclaim the mantle as the consolidator of the centrist wing of the party.  Klobuchar, Bloomberg, and Buttigieg will split the remainder of the centrist vote.  Steyer is a relative unknown, and South Carolina may signal the end of the line for him.  Bernie will win the majority of the liberal vote, with Warren hanging on.

For me, this is the hardest state to predict. Biden will almost certainly be coming off a third straight lackluster performance...will he be able to hold his best state? Prooooobably... but really ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
Just a guesstimate.  I think Buttegieg will pick up 12-14% of the "Someone else" votes.

Adjusting due to uncertainty around:
- how Biden's support is or isn't flagging.
- how Sanders is perceived among southern Democrats.

Joe Biden is spending most of his time in SC, but since he is looking vulnerable, I am unable to give him higher odds than 40%. Bernie is gaining momentum, but struggles with black voters. Someone else (Pete Buttegig) perhaps could do similar.
Took another look at polls and reporting. They all indicate Joe Biden.
It's Biden's to lose....and the way he's going...it'll feels like something perilously close to losing - like maybe just a 3 percentage point win.
Joe has a large base of support in SC

Biden has the resources and experience to warrant confidence in SC; it could be political bluster and his "don't give a damn" attitude will either hurt or help. My instincts tell me that SC could be the death knell for many a campaign. In Biden's case, it could be a narrow win or a major upset. https://www.270towin.com/2020-democratic-nomination/south-carolina-primary

Biden might still be popular in in SC. 538 seems to say so. He is seen though as losing favor as his gaffs and the ease of which he can be attacked diminished his perceived electability. Bernie has some momentum but so does Klobachur and Buttigieg.
relying on a strong Afro-American vote

I think Joe Biden is a white man black folks trust. But many folks of all colors live in the south and many educated people live in the south. If Buttegeig spends as much time in south Carloina putting his face to the world he will build support
It's coming down to Sanders for all of them. At this stage, there is no one else.

Joe Biden has higher chances obviously because of higher black population. Still Bernie has significant chance because of his consistent performance. That actually applicable for Pete too but he is lagging in black supporters. This does not mean that he will never get that demographics but SC is too near to recover that for him. Joe Biden knows that he has to win SC otherwise he has to drop much early than expected. He is on diminishing path one more time.

Throwing caution to wind. Had thought minorities would save sleepy Joe (prevailing “wisdom”). Thinking people are waking up and even SC doesn’t want to be left behind. Curious about Buttigieg and Klobuchar (always like Bernie and Amy - not sure if she’s truly winning people over for long haul but seems to have momentum). Not sure if Obama might support someone (swayed Canadian election when he did).
Someone please tell Clinton to stay away - lock her up.

Slightly decreasing estimate due to Biden's poor showing in New Hampshire and increasing Sanders/someone else (to account for Buttigieg momentum). However Biden's poor performance in New Hampshire (like Iowa) expected therefore changing estimates incrementally.
Biden may have a residual advantage from the Obama association. This is not a good state for Sanders and only slightly better for Warren.

THis is where we see what the Democratic Machine has left in her and who she pulls for, and who she pulls the rug from under..My guess is the establishment doesn't ant a consensus candidate to emerge from this race though...HRC is gonna get her shot.

538 says Biden, Sanders and Steyer. Biden has the nepotism optics problem, Sanders not releasing his health record and Steyer a bit wooden. Tough call. Mayor Pete is surging elsewhere and Klobachar is coming up. Party elite is thinking Bloomberg.
I'm thinking Buttigieg or Sanders but will not discount Warren just yet.

South Carolina will most likely stick true to Biden. The South is generally less predisposed to the progressive ideas of Warren and Bernie and more disposed to moderates. Therefore, Biden has always appealed to South Carolina and has lead every poll above the margin of error, frequently by double digits and often times by more than 20 points. While Biden's campaign has certainly stumbled in Iowa and will not recover in time for New Hampshire, South Carolina in far enough away for Biden to recover and flood the state with money to "reverse" his negative momentum. In this way South Carolina is Biden's bulwark and his campaign is going to assuredly spend the time and money to keep it that way.  Bernie has moderate support and presence in South Carolina, but there simply aren't enough progressives in the South to give Bernie a win in South Carolina.  The real wild card in Tom Steyer, who has strategically been spending his campaign money and time in South Carolina as his breakout state. Interestingly, Steyer seems to be pulling most of his support away from Warren. He may also been seen as an alternative to Biden, but ultimately, he is too progressive to really steal Biden's support. However, it remains unlikely that he'll win.  Buttigieg, the recent darling of the primary, has strategically little to no presence in South Carolina, as most candidates realize the impracticality of beating Biden here, also Buttigieg's sexual orientation will be a real turn off for many more socially conservative southern democrats. Therefore Buttigieg will no be winning South Carolina. Warren also has little to no presence or support and will not be winning much of anything in South Carolina. Especially considering how her support dwindled since the New year.  The ultimate Wild card, will be if Biden suspends his campaign after a resounding defeat in Nevada, but this is also highly unlikely, as strategically Biden should use South Carolina as a bulwark and his campaign is so high profile that they will want to stay in till South Carolina as a gauge for Biden's appeal for the South, because if Biden can win resoundingly win the South then he has a chance in a contested convention.  However, Biden's stumble might be enough to lower the enthusiasm of his voters, decreasing his turnout in South Carolina to the point where the "second place" winner might be able to take over. This is really where the South Carolina race is at, who can come in second and at this point it is statistically either Bernie or Steyer,

Looking at gambling odds which imply a roughly 60% probability for Biden and 40% for Sanders. Removed 3% from both probabilities to add to Steyer (5%) and Warren (1%). Polling for Steyer is improving, above Warren. Progressive leaning voters more likely to go with Sanders given momentum at the moment than Warren. Therefore Warren will lose voters to Sanders i believe. Steyer is spending vast amounts on ad spend in this State. Chances of someone else is close to zero (although not impossible!) but have put to zero.
Because of what happened in Iowa
How about a sure thing.  Warren and Sanders do not have the platform attractive to S.C. voters.
Biden has the South on lockdown!
Unfortunately I think slow Joe has this one...Bernie is picking up steam with black Americans but it won’t be quick enough to make a difference and older demographic slow to change.
